I’ve spoken previously about how supportive Alan has been and it was good to catch up. I met John (a data visualisation journalist), Chelsea (a social media journalist) and a few others. It was interesting being a random civil servant in a bar full of journalists. I’m a big fan of John’s work (and as it turns out Chelsea’s too). It was good to hear that John is a Newcastle United fan.FridayGovernment Statistical Service Presentation and Dissemination Symposium. I’ve outlined my thoughts/experiences of the event in the #daynotes here — although I only attended half of the event. Below is the stuff the happened in between.I packed my bags and headed to Victoria Street and collected my badge, it was lovely to see Tegwen (GSS Good Practice Team) and Neil (the departing Head of DWP Statistical Services) on the way in.The theme of the day was communication with impact, I’d been asked to talk about Churchill. I sat at the back with Matt, Rob and Catherine. I hadn’t seen Rob since the Graphical Web Conference in November, it was good to catch up briefly.After my session I chatted with Darren B (Open Data at ONS). We spoke about the challenges of ‘sorting out data’.I need to follow up with Darren.I also caught up with Hiren (from BEIS), Mark (a statto at DWP) and Mike who was my first ever boss in DWP. I haven’t seen Mike for ages so it was good to see him. I’d decided in the morning that I was going to leave the event at lunchtime to get back home at a reasonable time since I’d been away from all week so I hunted Rob down, who was with Darren W, to say goodbye before I dashed to the station.On the journey back I got a message from Catherine to say that DWP had won a presentation and dissemination award for our work on Churchill, Stat-Xplore, our interactive stats visualisation dashboards and gov.uk. A real cross team effort.I made it back home to see my daughters swimming training.That was my week.Clapping shows how much you appreciated Ryan Dunn’s story.Data Science Hub Lead @DWPDigital. These are my personal thoughts on my work week.tales from the internet of public service
column9: ReflectionThis has been quite an unusual week for me.From a practical point of view I’ve had a couple of shorter days in the office. This was partly to try and balance out next week which will also be very unusual as I will have a full week in London.Overall my mood this week has been one of reflection.Part of my reflection has been about people. Mostly in a positive way.I am fascinated -and drawn to- personality type tests. I’ve read quite a bit about the subject, its history and the analytical shortcomings of some of the more popular tests. It feels like a guilty pleasure.In Myers-Briggs I have always been INTJ — a barn owl in this test. I recognise the good and the bad in the descriptions. As I’m sure do the team.MondayI was a little later into the office as I wanted to wave my son off on his school residential.I caught up with Stuart (data scientist product owner for Churchill) over a coffee. He was back from leave so I brought him up to speed with some of the top level things. This ran over so I dialled in slightly late to the fortnightly catch up call with Charlie and our Digital Engagement team colleagues about comms.Daniel (data scientist) sent over a couple of gifs I’d asked for ahead of my Civil Service Live talk. I double checked some of the details of the analysis behind what was represented. During this discussion we both realised that the feature -which identified local, regional, multi-regional and national phenomenon- could be adapted for re-use across products. (I don’t think either of us could believe we hadn’t picked up on this sooner!)I tested everything worked as expected. The background to the gifs rendered better in Safari than Chrome or Firefox, so I loaded everything in Safari and double checked some Mac keyboard shortcuts.I then sat with Daniel and Sree (data scientist) to set off a conversation about how Sree’s work on state based sequences and lead lag dynamics might link with what Daniel and I had just realised about the identification of geographical phenomenon. Then I left them to it.I had a quick call with Charlie (my boss) then phoned Dan H (a GDS data scientist) to arrange to meet the following day.I exchanged a few messages on data visualisation.I headed out the door later than I wanted but had time for a very quick Lync chat with Sarah (Head of Labour Market Evidence and Narrative) who updated me on some progress following our conversation last week.TuesdayCivil Service Live 2017 day. In my home town, Gateshead. I was presenting which meant unfortunately I missed the DWP Women in Digital event in Leeds — but I did get a nice shoutout.I started the day in a quiet coffee shop -always nice. Emails and a bit of prep, checking I had presentation timings right. Then met Stuart, walked to the venue, registered and joined the opening address from John Manzoni (Chief Executive of the Civil Service).I then met Dan H for a coffee. Dan and I had spoken a few times but this was the first time we’d met face to face. We had a good chat, for about an hour and a half, part of which was an informal interview for the GDS Digital people blog. I talked about my experiences in growing the hub, my philosophy for the team and establishing our identity. I was open and honest and whenever Dan wrote down quotes I wondered whether I had said something controversial!Stuart joined Dan and I for a bit -we chatted about culture change and attitude- before heading off to a plenary session on leadership. John Manzoni again and Clare Moriarty (Permanent Secretary for Defra) with their reflections and experiences of leadership during uncertainty.John talked about creating stretching roles, setting context and helping people. Claire covered how uncertainty can produce paralysis and so openness and honesty in communicating during these times is very important. She used a great analogy about leaders needing to move between the balcony view and the dance floor view to provide context for people. Stuart and I both commented on how good -and very honest- Claire’s talk was.Then it was time for my cameo. I met Sarah (from Cabinet Office) and Dan to set up for our session on data for better decision making, policy and delivery. We had a few last minute tech things to sort out as I was demo-ing from my own machine.Dan topped and tailed the session. He talked about the Government Data Science Partnership (GDSP) — made up of the Cabinet Office, the Government Office for Science (GO Science) and the Office for National Statistics (ONS). He covered what data science is, where it is right now and where it is heading in Government. He finished with some information about the Data Science Accelerator Programme, communities and career paths and Data Literacy. I particularly liked this line…In between, I talked about setting up the hub in Newcastle, a bit about DWP Digital and multidisciplinary teams. I gave a demo of Churchill -explaining its importance in trailblazing the culture change and infrastructure development part- and a version of Greyhound and some of the other embedded analytics we have in the pipeline.The session seemed to go down well and generated a good variety of questions including around openness and ethics. A few people came up for a chat afterwards. There was interest in being involved in private beta for Churchill, I also pointed a couple of folk to the accelerator programme.Coincidentally, in the afternoon I bumped into Ian T (former DWP analyst, now at DEFRA). Ian is part of the next accelerator cohort who will be mentored in our hub, joining in a couple of weeks.I caught up for a chat Dawn (“data and policy nerd” at GDS) about the day and the city. We also spoke about a GDSP thing we are working on with Jane and Owen (from ONS).I got through a few emails, visited some of the Civil Service Live stalls and asked Kit for a favour before catching up with a friend for a drink on the quayside in the early evening sun.WednesdayWorking from home day. This started with lying with my daughter on her bed watching a storm out of the window. Thankfully this came to a sudden stop in time for me to walk her to school.I did some thinking about a couple of potential pitches -around data- for the OneTeamGov unconference. Perhaps subliminally prompted by the fact that Kit had been so great about the favour I’d asked the day before.I spent a lot of the day on emails and admin as I tend to do on Wednesdays. I had an early evening meeting at my son’s new secondary school -which meant I couldn’t travel to London that day for another meeting. Seeing his new form teacher made me feel very old.ThursdayA half day. I went into the office in the morning.I caught up with Alaine (our delivery lead) ahead of her well earned two weeks holiday. We spoke about funding, contracts, production environments, IT health check plus other private beta preparation activities. I then caught up with Stuart we discussed the various presentations we have to deliver next week.I had a discussion around the practical challenges of embedding analytics within our products.I left early to watch my son’s school cricket and spend the rest of the afternoon with him since he was back from his residential. I had another meeting at the new secondary school, this one about music.Later in the day I spoke to Charlie about monkeys and typewriters.FridayEmails then a catch up with Joana and Gayll about Greyhound ahead of some upcoming meetings they had lined up. I outlined my views on a few things and we separated out some of the challenges.I grabbed a coffee on my way into a Churchill design meeting with Stuart, Dave D (business analyst), Dave R and Massimo (developers) to discuss priorities for the next two sprints. I like these meetings, I can’t always get to them. We were all honest and pragmatic and eventually covered (almost) everything Dave D wanted us to in the two hours. I then had a phone call with Paul A.I sat with Michael who wanted to chat with me about a data visualisation design challenge he was facing. As it happened it was virtually identical to something Adam and I had tackled in detail relatively recently. I grabbed Adam, we talked Michael through a couple of solutions, shared some code and showed a similar example from Tom’s statistics team’s work. A perfect example of our data vis design community in action.Adam then talked me through progress with the data visualisation awareness material — its looking really good.I had a really positive call with Gayll and Iu to discuss modelling with encrypted data and then joined the weekly Lync session between the team and Charlie.I walked out the office at about half five which, since I went to the right pool this week, meant I got to see my daughter’s swimming trainingThat was my week.Clapping shows how much you appreciated Ryan Dunn’s story.Data Science Hub Lead @DWPDigital. These are my personal thoughts on my work week.tales from the internet of public service
column10: PrideI complained last week of having very little thinking time. I had a little more this week, I include some aspects of that below.My overall feeling at the end of this week was pride. I’m immensely proud of our team, individually and collectively. I’m proud of what we’ve achieved in the relatively short time we’ve been together especially given some of the wider context which I won’t bore people with.Some time ago I toyed with the GTD productivity/time management method. Part of this involves working from a regularly empty inbox. I still use some of the principles but I have rarely been near inbox zero. Recently -for reasons I can’t quite establish- I decided to aim for that target as I was convinced it would somehow ‘make me feel better’. I failed big time this week.Monday morning was emailsDave R popped up to talk about the new UI features he’s prototyping for Churchill. I explained my related thoughts on the how the Statistical Services dashboard products should/could/will fit within our developing family of applications and how users should be able to move between exploratory and explanatory aspects seamlessly.Then I Lynced into the regular Data and Analytics Directorate Grade 6 forum. We covered, amongst other things feedback from the site ‘stand ups’ -which I mentioned last week- and a discussion about a leadership initiative we are rolling out across the directorate.After the call I caught up with Dave D about more feedback from Churchill users. I asked a few questions about where we were with the current sprint ahead of Tuesday’s mid-sprint session and a gave Dave my high level thoughts on some aspects of scope, scheduling and prioritisation for the next couple of sprints relating to our move to private beta.I popped for a chat about arrangements for the Next Tech Girls initiative in Newcastle and later had an interesting call which Kate (from the Data and Analytics Gateway team) chaired, about some potential discovery work — hopefully more to come on this.I spoke with Becky about an upcoming board meeting where trialling Manhattan would be discussed and we needed to supply some documentation. We had a few outstanding questions which meant I needed to try and catch Kevin H (who is responsible for security and operational control within Data and Analytics) for a chat about data and role based access. Coincidentally Kev appeared at my desk and asked if I’d pop into a meeting he was in to give a short demo. I didn’t get to ask my questions though.The impromptu presentation meant I left the office a lot later than intended. On the commute home I was pleased to see the tweet below. The short video features Becky, Joana and Daniel from the team. I loved what they -and of course the others in the video- had to say.TuesdayFelt like telephone day, I was pleased to have a headset.I popped to Sree’s desk when I arrived as she wanted a chat about the ideas we’d discussed on Friday around state based sequences and the research papers I’d shared. It was a good chat. Sree talked through her initial ideas and I gave my views on which data to use initially.I’m really excited about this piece of work. Its part of a theme of activity to develop some fantastically reusable embedded analytics pipelines for our applications. The particular area that Sree is investigating is one that I’ve thought about a lot and been keen to explore for a very, very long time.This stuff could be incredibly powerful.Joana joined the conversation when she arrived in the office and we discussed how Sree’s work could bridge a few other pieces of work, including the aspects of Greyhound which Joana is working on. Then I collared Kevin and he came and sat with Becky and I for five minutes to answer our questions. This meant we could get the board meeting papers ready. We’re treading new ground with a lot of our work so we’re very careful to ensure we’re well informed on the data protection, security and legal aspects of what we do. In that way we can be confident to innovate appropriately. Becky has been incredible.I met with Alaine and Ash (who is amazing and runs the software development team in Data and Analytics) ahead of a -potentially very long- call about Directorate level planning for the remainder of 17/18. Alaine had been in Sheffield the day before supporting the planning and needed a couple of things from Ash. I’d hoped that this, plus the prep we all did last week, would pretty much finalise our part of the plans. Which in turn would mean I wouldn’t be needed for all of the planning call.Ahead of the call I grabbed five minutes with Daniel to plant an idea in his head for embedded analytics to automatically identify certain features in Churchill .I joined the planning call for a short while but had to dip out to call Dawn about the Government Data Science Partnership Civil Service Live Session at Sage Gateshead on Tuesday June 20. Dawn had asked me last week if I’d make a guest speaker cameo covering the work of our Hub. So we had a chat about the details. We also spoke about the data literacy strand of work within GDS which sounds really good.I rejoined the planning call and then we all took a break to dial into an all staff call for DWP Digital with Mayank.Alaine informed me I didn’t need to dial into the remainder of the planning call -result- so I reviewed the board meeting papers that Becky had pulled together and then caught up with Alaine to discuss the planning meeting actions -me to speak to David B (from our data architecture team) about platforms and architecture- so we set up a call for the following day.Since I’d left late the day before I decided to use the commute home to dial into another all staff call this time for the whole of DWP. That made it around four hours on the phone during the day which is very unusual and not altogether pleasant.I made it back in time to walk my son home from school and have a coffee with my Mam before we collected my daughter from after school football.WednesdayWorking from home day. Quite a bit of admin, logistics and emails in the morning, during which I (finally) saw Lisa’s Open Vis Conference talk which talks about empathy vs rationality in data visualisation. It’s very, very good and made me think more about the human side of the data in our products.Charlie called for our rearranged fortnightly catch up. We mainly talked about Churchill private beta and the 17/18 planning work. Then we both dialled into the weekly prioritisation call with the others hubs. Its always good to hear what everyone else is getting up to.In the afternoon I started some prep for the Civil Service Live talk including a chat with Daniel about some gifs he’d previously produced. I messaged Steve A (who is a developer in Ash’s team) to arrange to get a physical build of Churchill on my MacBook for me to demo on the day. I responded to a few emails and set up a few chats for later in the week.In between all that I had a call with David B, Paul G (agile delivery manager), Alaine and Ash about architecture and platforms in relation to 17/18 plans. A positive meeting which untangled a few things and clarified what is for now and what is for later.I headed off to collect my son from school, we went for a walk. I bought some Jelly Tots. I had a quick exchange with Stephen about AWS Virtual Private clouds and networking virtual servers (Stephen has promised to educate me further, he has a remarkable talent for explanation) then collected my daughter from after school guitar lessons.ThursdayI had a very full calendar. I grabbed a chat with Joana first thing about Greyhound, local economy data and models and then a quick conversation with Becky about the board meeting papers for Manhattan.My first scheduled meeting was the regular catch up with Alaine. I have different types of meetings with different people in the team. I have asked people what they prefer — for example Stuart (product owner for Churchill) and I tend to have short walking meetings as and when we need to talk. Alaine’s preference is a regular meeting in the calendar. I haven’t got it quite right on team comms yet but hoping my #weeknotes will help with that a little.I grabbed a coffee and we talked a bit about the past week or so, covered some staffing stuff and looked ahead to the next quarter and rest of the year both in team terms and personal/career development. It was a good chat.I had another quick chat with Daniel about gifs and he sent me a version of Greyhound to load onto my MacBook for Civil Service Live. Then it was straight into a call with Sarah (Head of Labour Market Evidence and Narrative) about possible links between two areas of our work. It was an informative conversation.I was slightly late for the meeting/call with Adam, Stephen, Mark and Paul to feedback on the current version of the data visualisation material. I hadn’t devoted as much time to reviewing it as I’d wanted to but we made good progress and there were some good challenges to ideas.Then it was a cross-Digital call about DWP Digital practices, job families and roles which meant Corinne (Head of Data and Analytics Live Services) and I couldn’t have our regular call. Before I left I managed to read and sign off the final version of our contribution to the 17/18 plan.FridayI popped downstairs to give my MacBook to Alastair (one of the developers working on Churchill) to put the local build on it and then caught up with Michael (UI developer) about a few things. I always have good conversations with Michael, I think I’ve converted him in terms of how he looks at data visualisation design and he has introduced me to important user experience concepts.I tried to structure some of my thoughts for Civil Service Live and then joined a Lync session with James (part of the Digital Transformation Team in the DWP Operational Control Centre) to show him Greyhound. This was set up following Kit’s workshop a couple of weeks back. During the lunch break of the workshop I showed the application to Deborah (Head of Universal Credit Digital Transformation) and Jackie (who manages Digital Transformation in the Operational Control Centre). Jackie saw potential uses in her area and set up the meeting with James.It was a really positive call. James was very complementary of Greyhound and the ‘strategic lens’ is offers. He gave us some background of his area and we agreed to follow up with a visit.Pleasingly, a big theme of the conversation on both sides was about the importance of context. At a high level my questions to James were -if you had all the data you’re asking for, what would you do with it?I popped down to chat with Dave R about the prototype Churchill UI features.Dave R is never going to design an invisible interface to data but together we’re trying to make sure the data is the star of the show. The challenge is how to iterate to where we want to be without disrupting the experience along the way. Dave R is really patient with me and often has an idea waiting before I’ve asked the question.Alastair dropped my MacBook back to me which meant I could do a little more preparation for Civil Service Live including a quick chat with Daniel to discuss the material he was supplying and to borrow some cables and adapters from him and test a few things -live demos are probably more informative than slides but do carry more risk!I joined the weekly Greyhound/Manhattan Lync session with Charlie. Then since I had no chance of making inbox zero, I got down to inbox 100 before heading to my daughters swimming training.That was my week.Clapping shows how much you appreciated Ryan Dunn’s story.Data Science Hub Lead @DWPDigital. These are my personal thoughts on my work week.tales from the internet of public service
column11: FrustrationFirst time writing week notes. Inspired by Matt and Dan (whose format I have shamelessly adopted here). Thought I’d give it a go.At the very least writing this stuff down was useful to me.I covered who me is in Matt’s What is it you actually do? I lead the Data Science Hub for the Department for Work and Pensions in Newcastle. Effectively an R&D function in Digital, Data and Analytics. We design, prototype and pilot data-driven and embedded-analytics products. This is to support, inform and transform strategy, policy and operations.For context and reference, since this is my first #weeknotes I’ve included more detail than I would normally intend to.This week felt like a lot of meetings, emails and planning activity which left me little thinking time. So my overall feeling at the end of the week was frustration. Although in writing this stuff down I probably covered more of what I like — working with the team on the detail — than it felt.I was on leave for half term and came into the office on Monday morning, after a Sunday evening email skim read and triage, with a plan and a list of half a dozen tasks I wanted to complete that day.After a quick catch up with a few people I ticked number one off the list. I sent out an article “Hands up if you don’t like data!” to the area of the department responsible for current and future policy.The article was comms about Churchill one of our products which I’ve blogged about here. The ultra high level user story isI then caught up with Dave D (our business analyst) to discuss the Churchill user engagement and feedback that had taken place while I was on leave.Some Monday meetings had parachuted into my calendar while I was on leave. The first was a late morning call with Max (program manager for Data Science) which blew my plan and list out of the water. Max called about the work of my team for 17/18. This year is focused on scaling.In practice this means working with Data Engineering colleagues to continue to develop our cloud based platform, design standards, APIs/Microservices and analytics that underpin — and are embedded into — our Data Science products and are enablers for future products. It also means focusing on creating families of applications that work together and appreciate the context of the users so they can move between them seamlessly.The outcome of that call meant providing some more detail on deliverables, resources, indicative costs and such like for the rest of the year to take to a meeting on Thursday — which had a pre-meeting call on Wednesday — lovely.
